title: Update SYSTEM_REQUIREMENTS.txt and update Java-7-known-to-work version numbers before release of Lucene/Solr 4.8
description:
Since Solr 4.8 will require Java 7 as a minimum, the description in the SYSTEM_REQUIREMENTS.txt need to be updated too. 

Or maybe it should be merged into release notes. All it will probably have is use Java version after u56 (or whatever) and here is an obscure URL to known bugs (still valid for Java 7?).

comments.author: Uwe Schindler
comments.content:
Where is the problem? This is fixed since a long time for 4.8. These are the contents of the SYSTEM_REQUIREMENTS,txt/html in lucene and solr folder of the distrbution:


# System Requirements 

Apache Solr runs of Java 7 or greater. When using Java 7, be sure to 
install at least Update 1! With all Java versions it is strongly 
recommended to not use experimental `-XX` JVM options. It is also 
recommended to always use the latest update version of your Java VM, 
because bugs may affect Solr. An overview of known JVM bugs can be 
found on http://wiki.apache.org/lucene-java/JavaBugs. 

CPU, disk and memory requirements are based on the many choices made in 
implementing Solr (document size, number of documents, and number of 
hits retrieved to name a few). The benchmarks page has some information 
related to performance on particular platforms.

comments.author: Uwe Schindler
comments.content: The CHANGES.txt also contains the Java 7 information.

comments.author: Alexandre Rafalovitch
comments.content:
Do we need this file at all? It seems still in the trunk.

Also, I thought there were bugs in Java 7 and Update 1+ is no longer a recommended version, but something released last week?

Finally, the JavaBugs page, can we easily tell which of these issue still apply to Java 7. Or are they all now legacy for previous Solr release?

It's not a "Problem" as such, just trying to see if something like this still has value to the users or whether that information is better merged with where the users would actually look for it (CHANGES, Release Notes, etc).

comments.author: Uwe Schindler
comments.content:
Do we need this file at all? It seems still in the trunk.

Yes, it is part of the HTML documentation, too. In trunk, the version is also Java 7, so the file is correct for all 3 branches: trunk, branch_4x and lucene_solr_4_8.

Also, I thought there were bugs in Java 7 and Update 1+ is no longer a recommended version, but something released last week?

I will update this section together with the web site once our tests have finished. This goes in line with my release schedule.

It's not a "Problem" as such, just trying to see if something like this still has value to the users or whether that information is better merged with where the users would actually look for it (CHANGES, Release Notes, etc).

It is part of the main documentation, so every user will see it. Also the CHANGES.txt and the release note will also contain it,

Example from 4.7.2 (Java 6): http://lucene.apache.org/core/4_7_2/ -> "System requirements" link. The file is formatted in Markdown and is part of the HTML pages of the release, because the build process converts it to HTML.

Finally, the JavaBugs page, can we easily tell which of these issue still apply to Java 7. Or are they all now legacy for previous Solr release?

This page is up-to-date. It also contains a version number for every problem and if it is fixed. The links there are up-to date and also "older" bugs still apply (like NIOFSDirectory unuseable on Windows,...).

comments.author: Alexandre Rafalovitch
comments.content:
If it's all on TODO list and makes sense to others, I don't have any issues with the file itself. Just was trying to make sure it was not missed and did not see any other issues about it. Did not think to look for specific release checklist (is it public on Wiki?)

With the JavaBugs page, I am not saying it is out of date. I am saying it is hard to understand at the glance whether it applies to whatever I am running. So, when we move to Java 7 and recommend the latest u60+, how much of that page will be relevant to those users? Can we put the issues that are still open/affect even u60+ on the top and move the rest into the noticeably different section?

But perhaps it is a different issue and different discussion.

comments.author: Uwe Schindler
comments.content:
If it's all on TODO list and makes sense to others, I don't have any issues with the file itself. Just was trying to make sure it was not missed and did not see any other issues about it. Did not think to look for specific release checklist (is it public on Wiki?)

Lucene/Solr 4.8 is a special release because of this change to Java 7, so it is on my private TODO list (I am the release manager). There was already a mail by Robert Muir this morning that mentions updating the reqirement page and website, if Java 7u55 proves to not have the superword bug. The testing is going on. Once we had several successful runs, I will start a release candidate of Lucene 4.8 with the updated SYSREQ page.

I will change the issue title to update the SYSREQ page before building release candidates.

comments.author: Uwe Schindler
comments.content:
With the JavaBugs page, I am not saying it is out of date. I am saying it is hard to understand at the glance whether it applies to whatever I am running. So, when we move to Java 7 and recommend the latest u60+, how much of that page will be relevant to those users? Can we put the issues that are still open/affect even u60+ on the top and move the rest into the noticeably different section?

But perhaps it is a different issue and different discussion.

Feel free to update this page in the Wiki! I try to update them whenever we find new bugs and issues. Unfortunately, it is not always easy to check that every bug is still valid, so it is better to keep them in the list.

In addition, we have lots of users, still using Lucene 2.9.x / Solr 1.4.x and Lucene/Solr 3.6.x. For those people we should keep the complete list of bugs, especially to help them if they hit one of these bugs to help them to workaround.

Sorting the page by version numbers could be done, yes (like we do for JDK vendors).
